captions.text:
I gaze upon them
before I part.

They lie in their bed, unaware
of me watching.

The small home I help provide
is their world.

They explore--learning to move,
to feel, to see, to

know--not once thinking of
how it all came to be.

Crayons, toys, books--it's
all for them.

The fridge opens, the
pantry exposed.
They expect food to be there.

Cereal, milk, yogurt, messy
fingers, messy faces--all fed.

Once again they lie
in the comfort we

I'm far but close, always
thinking of them.

My wife's phone is
now missing.
I do it all for them.
I work that they may grow.
How I yearn to do the same.

They see so little of how
it all came to be--never
I come home to second hugs.

Once again they lay
their heads on
I will be their gentle friend.

I will be my wife's
faithful husband.

And while I may not understand
all that He does for me, I do

know that all that I am and
all that I have is because

I now stand very aware of
how it all came to be.

comments.text:
I am not a husband or a father...yet, but I honestly can't wait!  I think 
it is very special that our Heavenly Father has given us an opportunity to 
enjoy a little bit of what He does.  I know parenthood isn't always 
glamorous, but I am pretty sure that any parent who understands their role 
wouldn't give it up for the world.﻿
comments.author: Andrew Prince

comments.text:
My daughter wrote a poem for me when she was 10 years old and gave it to me 
for Father's Day. The poem looks at herself through my eyes and imagines 
moving together into the future. What amazing insight for a 10-year-old. 
The incredible thing is the foreshadowing in the stanza "As time goes by, 
you'll grow and you'll leave. As time goes by your own goals you'll 
achieve." She is now 22 and living in Stockholm.  I wrote music for her 
poem, recorded it, and gave it back to her for Christmas 2014. 
http://youtu.be/Prs00nuyq3I﻿

comments.text:
Temple ordinances are given to further our growth as people and spiritual 
beings as well as a way to connect our families to our ancestors through 
generations.

Some of us may change our minds now due to our incomplete knowledge of the 
gospel as we went through the veil of forgetfulness, but in the life after 
we shall fully understand; that is why our life here is a test based on our 
faith and work and who we become as a result of this, not just a test of 
how many sins we make.

When we reach the life after, I believe we will be judged not only in 
accordance of our works and relationships with others, but who we've become 
as a person.

George, I ask of you, please, ask of Heavenly Father for only he has all 
the answers. In time he may reveal revelations unto you in regards to what 
you seek. Night! ^_^
comments.author: Platypus-Books

comments.text:

comments.author: George Squires

comments.text:
+George Squires  I think Heavenly Father lets us choose which path to take, 
and that includes our choice and stance in marriage. This is where faith 
and work come into play. Heavenly Father knows of the potential multiple 
paths we are able to take now and in the future; however, it is based on 
how we choose to conduct ourselves that determines which path we walk with 
the resulting blessings according to our faith and work. Eternal marriage 
is eternal based on our decisions and how appropriately we choose to act. 
Though, the inner workings of marriage must be way more complicated than 
how I'm explaining since I'm just trying to be realistic with no experience 
to speak of whatsoever.

George, I thank you for questioning a matter, but don't just continually 
ask us these questions here. I think it would be best is you could find a 
missionary couple that's within your area. Missionary couples are married 
elders where the wife and husband have decided to serve a mission together. 
I think they would have an answer..., but also please, pray about this if 
you truly do hunger for the answer.

Have a nice day (or morning as it's very early where I'm at)!
comments.author: Platypus-Books

place?  How is an Eternal Marriage not ETERNAL?

comments.author: George Squires

comments.text:
I glad to have helped, if I did at all since my answers are more based off 
of speculation and observation rather than experience.

I'm honestly sad that that has happened, but their reasons for doing so are 
their own and must have happened with good reason. I do agree that the 
option to break a temple sealing is controversial, and maybe even a bit of 
a temptation, but to even have the option - I feel that there's a reason as 
to why the church even offers it. I personally may not know why, but it 
must exists for a complex and confusing reason.

These families that you know were given the option, and took it. They may 
be experiencing heartache now, but perhaps in time those involved may learn 
something from this or grow from this.

I'm sorry, I just don't have all the answers. I hope I helped you as much 
as I can as someone who's just discussing this with you on a youtube 
comment section.

If you're still hungering for an answer, you could always talk (in private 
if you wish so) to the bishop of LDS ward that's in the area where you 
live. I feel that he would be far more knowledgeable than I in this area. 
It's late where I'm at so goodnight! ^_^
comments.author: Platypus-Books

comments.text:
+Platypus-Books Marriage is not "until we grow apart" or "so long as love 
endures."  You are the single person who has attempted to answer this.  So 
for this I thank you.  Marriage is also a cross, which perfects and and we 
are to lead our partner back to God.  I sadly know MANY LDS couples who 
have children sealed to them who have had Temple Divorce.  It is no good. 
 The Church ought not make this possible.
comments.author: George Squires

comments.text:
Well, I think it's all down to people's circumstances. I personally don't 
know anyone who has had a temple divorce, but from what I was taught, this 
can happen when the couple aren't compatible for each other anymore. People 
grow in different ways, so I guess some can grow apart.

I haven't exactly read anything that was specifically about divorce in the 
scriptures, although I'm not the most studious person, but I thought 
adultery was only when a married wife or husband were untrue to their 
spouse while still being married. Sorry, I'm a little unclear to what's 
being asked.

Why it's tolerated? Well, like legal divorce there can be a falling out 
between the couple, especially if they both aren't trying to mend their 
bond or are really just incompatible, finding this out latter in life. It 
does make a mess of things, but if there were two people who clearly didn't 
want to be together, I think it would be best to separate them; of course 
only after years of pondering if this is the best course of action - 
especially considering how the children are and will be effected. So why 
it's tolerated is because it's the final course of action if all other 
things fail, proving that the couple really are just incompatible with each 
other.

Taking marriage courses before marriage is (I think, since I'm not married) 
more of a personal choice and is up to the couple. If they truly want it, 
then they can; if they don't, then they don't. It's their free agency to 
choose.

I hope I answered your questions well enough as deep doctrine can be either 
vague or complex from what I'm studying right now. I'm not married so I'm 
not sure how the whole process of sealing and divorce goes.

Um, and sorry about writing so much - hope this doesn't hurt your eyes with 
the display's LED lights and all that. I hope you have a wonderful day too! 
^_^
comments.author: Platypus-Books

comments.text:
+Platypus-Books Yes, thank you.  But this creates a mess.  Why are the 
family allowed to have a Temple Divorce and then permitted to remarry? 
 Isn't this why Jesus said to divorce and take another wife is adultery? 
 The whole family is messed up by this.  Why tolerate it?  Are Mormons 
required to take any marriage prep courses before marriage?
comments.author: George Squires

comments.text:
Hi! I know this was a month ago that you asked this question, and though I 
may not be a missionary - I hope that I can answer your question as best as 
I can.

So just to make sure I got this clear; you're question is about temple 
sealing - of when a man and a woman are sealed together, then there's a 
fallout and then they get divorced. The previous couple are then re-sealed 
to their new spouse, and your asking who the children are actually sealed 
to after all of that has happened, correct?

Well, to tell you the truth, breaking the bond to the person someone is 
sealed to is a very serious matter and is in fact harder to administer than 
a legal divorce. The couple must truly ponder whether they want to break 
this spiritual bond that they have not only with each other, but with their 
children. Breaking a temple sealing is the last resort if the couple had 
tried everything they could to make their relationship better and healthier 
as the person they're sealed to is supposed to be their husband or wife for 
all eternity.

If there really is no other option, then they must write a request to the 
prophet, and he will determine whether to accept the request while fasting 
and praying. Breaking a temple sealing is basically breaking a sacred 
covenant (well, in my eyes), you're essentially cutting the spiritual link 
of not only someone you vowed to spend eternity with, but you're also 
breaking this link with you're children.

Now onto the second part of your question. If the the two re-married and 
were sealed to their new husband or wife, the children that the two had 
together wouldn't be sealed to the mother or father (whoever is breaking 
the seal), essentially this could be equated to "the breaker of the seal" 
"spiritually disowning" the children they had been previously sealed to. In 
the next life, the children that were born on earth won't see them as their 
parent, but just someone who they spent time on earth with - the same goes 
for the parent who broke the seal; as they won't recognize their children 
as being spiritually "their's", but just people who they knew.

I hope this answer was informative enough for you. In all honesty, me being 
a lds member and 19 years old, people would think I know a lot - but I 
don't, so please excuse me if my answer was confusing or unclear as this is 
very deep doctrine.

If the missionaries you know aren't that well versed in a particular 
subject, try asking the bishop of the ward they attend or online 
missionaries on lds,org.

I hope this helped! ^_^
comments.author: Platypus-Books

comments.text:
+kuroka13 Okay, but if the children are sealed to the divorced and resealed 
parents, this brings a bit of confusion.
comments.author: George Squires

comments.text:
Sealings to a spouse and sealings to children are separate, even though 
they might be performed in the same event. In a temple divorce, the sealing 
of the children to parents is not broken because their sealing was not the 
same as the marriage. A good example is when sealings occur by proxy. The 
parents are sealed, then each child is sealed to his/her parent. I suppose 
the handbook (I assume you mean handbook 2 - which covers local 
administration mostly) doesn't mention anything because each sealing is 
technically separate (marriage vs. children to parents). As a side note, 
covenant breaking by the parents does not void the sealing of the children. 
To some extent, you can think of the sealing connection as you would the 
actual relationships in the family. Mom and Dad might not be husband and 
wife anymore, but Billy and Susie are still their children. I hope this 
helps.
comments.author: kuroka13
